newsitem.title: UK: British media group United News profit up after merger.
newsitem.headline: British media group United News profit up after merger.

text.p: British television and national newspaper group United News & Media Plc said Friday its profits rose 12 percent in the first year of a merger which effectively doubled its size.

A media heavyweight was created last year when United News, publisher of national newspapers The Express and Daily Star, joined forces with commercial television and financial services group MAI in a three billion pound ($4.8 billion) deal.

The company said 1996 profits before tax and one-time items rose 12 percent, slightly better than expected, to 290.2 million pounds ($466.0 million). Earnings per share grew 15 percent to 40 pence (64 cents).
"I think we have delivered at the top end of expectations against the agenda we set ourselves at the time of the merger," Chief Executive Clive Hollick said.

"The review of the businesses following the merger has been completed, with adjustments to the portfolio in some areas and changed operating strategies in others," said Hollick, who moved across from MAI.

United said savings as a result of the merger and subsequent restructuring were expected to reach 43 million pounds ($69 million) a year by 1998. It took a one-time charge of 56 million pounds ($89.9 million) last year, mainly stemming from the merger.

The company has been active on the disposals and acquisitions front, spending more than 750 million pounds ($1.2 billion) last year as it bought exhibitions group Blenheim and a 29.9 percent stake in regional television broadcaster HTV .
It recouped around 300 million ($481.7 million) by selling a finance company, a legal publisher and local newspaper interests.

United, which operates commercial television (ITV) franchises in southern and eastern England, said operating profit from its broadcasting and entertainment division rose by 36 percent to almost 60 million pounds ($96.3 million).
Profit from the business services unit grew 38 percent to 100.5 million ($161.4 million) but the contribution from financial services edged down to 51.1 million ($82 million).
Earnings from consumer publishing dropped 7.5 percent to 81 million ($130 million) after a 31 million pound ($49.8 million) increase in paper costs.
Hollick said restructuring of the national newspapers should save 15 million pounds ($24.1 million) a year, some of which would be ploughed back into the papers.
The mid-market Daily and Sunday Express newspapers have been relaunched as a combined seven-day operation in a bid to end a long-term sales decline.
